w:r.w:t: ATW Load Planning App — Hosting Requirements
The ATW Load Planning App supports the load planning team's daily batching process — planners import open order data via CSV, review system-generated load proposals,

, and key outputs directly into Sugar. The app operates as a standalone tool and does not directly connect to or modify any ATW systems. The requirements below define what the hosting environment needs to
the shipping team to use it reliably during business hours.
Page loads, order review, approvals — target < 30 seconds
CSV import + full optimization run — up to 90 seconds acceptable
writable volume for the SQLite database file and app-generated output files, persisted across container restarts
TLS termination with a stable, accessible URL for end users
environment-variable injection for application credentials — no hardcoded secrets in source
sufficient CPU and memory for 8–10 concurrent users with periodic CPU-intensive optimization jobs; ~2 vCPU / 4 GB RAM is a reasonable starting point
must support request durations up to 90 seconds, or provide async/background job execution for long-running operations
platform-level logs with basic availability alerting (restarts, high error rate)
ability to deploy updates and roll back if needed
Example Specification — Azure App Service P1v3

The following is one example of a commercially available hosting configuration that meets the requirements above. It is provided as a reference point, not a prescription — equivalent options from other providers or tiers will work equally well if the core requirements are satisfied.
Mount an Azure File Share to the container for SQLite database and output files
Enabled by default via azurewebsites.net domain; custom domain optional
Set environment variables via App Service "Configuration" > Application Settings
Enable App Service Diagnostics Logs + Azure Monitor for availability alerting
Deploy via Docker Hub, Azure Container Registry, or direct image push

Estimated setup time for a straightforward deployment: 4–8 hours for an IT professional familiar with Azure, assuming the Docker image is provided and ready to deploy. This includes provisioning the App Service plan, configuring storage, setting environment variables, validating HTTPS access, and
file-based and single-writer by design; not suited for multi-instance horizontal scaling. If active-active scaling is required, plan for migration to a managed relational database
CPU-intensive during business hours — provision accordingly or consider burst-capable compute tiers
non-critical system; brief downtime for restarts or deployments is acceptable
Reach out to the project team with any questions on app architecture or deployment specifics.
